0.title: Stoxy
0.headline: Stoxy
0.body:
The reactive state management system equipped with Web Components 


  
    Follow Guides 
  
    Browse Docs

1.title: Stoxy
1.headline: Why Stoxy?Small
1.body: No dependencies and no need for build tools.

2.title: Stoxy
2.headline: Global state
2.body: Handle state across the whole application, with immediate response from components.

3.title: Stoxy
3.headline: Zero Configuration
3.body: With plug and play implementation, you're up and running in just a single line of code.

4.title: Stoxy
4.headline: Extensive tooling
4.body: Stoxy ships with framework agnostic components to use with the state management system to achieve optimal results with your Web Application.

5.title: Stoxy
5.headline: Extendability
5.body: Built with small and powerful functions, allowing you to extend the functionality with predicates and delegates.

6.title: Stoxy
6.headline: Offline-ready
6.body: Stoxy can utilize the IndexedDB for storage, allowing you to create offline-first experiences without the hassle.

7.title: Docs
7.headline: DocsMotivation

8.title: Docs
8.headline: Simplicity
8.body:
All of Stoxy's commands are 1-2 parameters long, and can be executed as "one-liners". 
They are however extremely extendable due to the nature of the state management system of Stoxy. Some of the Stoxy core
functions like update  and remove   even take delegates or predicates as a parameter to give the developer
more control over their state management.

9.title: Docs
9.headline: Ecosystem
9.body:
Stoxy ships with a small set of Web Components, which are framework agnostic components ready for use in any project. 
The components are built to as reactive pieces of an application, updating their contents accordin to state
change without the developer having to do any work.

10.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object

14.title: Methods: Persist Key
14.headline: Methods: Persist Key
14.body:
Declare a state object to be persisted through pageloads. 
Stoxy utilized IndexedDB to persist state objects. There could be two reasons you would want to persist your state objects: 

Persisted state objects are peristed through page page reloads / sessions 
Persisted state objects can be removed from cache, and only fetched when needed

15.body: Name Attribute   keyOrKeys One or more keys as string, separated by a comma

Returns a promise, which when resolved contains the state object data.

20.title: Mixins: Element Mixin
20.headline: Installation
20.body:
Install Stoxy  into your dependencies 
npm install @stoxy/core
  
Then install this library to enable the mixin support 
npm install @stoxy/element-mixin

a.title: Docs
a.headline: Persistence
a.body:
Stoxy comes shipped with persistence out of the box. There are many cases in which it is beneficial to persist the state
data through page reloads and navigation. Wether it be stale-while-revalidate patterns, or just static information fetched
from the API. 
The Persistence in Stoxy is opt-in, meaning that you control exactly what information gets persisted.

b.title: Docs
b.headline: Use them how you want to
b.body:
The whole core set of Stoxy is built from smaller modules, which can be attached at will. 
This means that you can use Stoxy only for managing state, and then handle all the events through subscribers,
or you can go all in on Stoxy and deploy a whole application built with stoxy elements using barely any Javascript 

  
    
        
         
       

  Show Navigation

c.title: Guides
c.headline: Guides
c.body:
In the guides section you can find multiple examples of utilizing Stoxy and Stoxy Elements 

  
    
        
         
       

  Show Navigation

e.title: Components: Stoxy Form
e.headline: Components: Stoxy Form
e.body:
Stoxy Form is a web component used for handling Stoxy state without
having to write any javascript. 
On submit, the form persists the form's data to state with the given key attribute. 
If the url attribute is set, the form creates a HTTP request before saving the data to state.

f.title: Components: Stoxy Form
f.headline: Attributes
f.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Either add  or set  dependeing on wanted to add to a colleciton in state, or deplace the state  url In some cases you might want to send the form data to the backend. For these situations you can declare the url property. If set, sends a fetch request to given url on submit.  method If url is set, specifies the HTTP method used for the request. Defaults to GET  requireok If url is set, specifies if the HTTP request is required to return a OK status before committing the object to state.

g.title: Components: Stoxy Form
g.headline: Usage

h.title: Components: Stoxy Form
h.headline: Sending the form data to a API on submit
h.body:
In some cases we might want to send the data from the form to a backend API while we save it to our state at the
same time. This can be done by utilizing the stoxy-form's url  attribute. 
import  '@stoxy/form' ; 
  
<stoxy-form
    key="todos"
    action="add"
    url="https://my-website.app/todoadd"
    method="POST"
    requireok
    @submit=${() => {
         this.shadowRoot.querySelector('input').value = '';
    }}
>
    < input 
        type = " text"  
        name = " task"  
        placeholder = " Add todo..."  
        autocomplete = " off"  
    />  
    < input  type = " submit"   value = " Submit"   />  
</ stoxy-form >  

  
In the above case, a POST request would be made to https://my-website.app/todoadd , with the body
{ task: "Your input" } . 
The requireok  attribute means that unless we get a OK response from the backend, we won't save the
data to state either. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

i.title: Components: Stoxy String
i.headline: Components: Stoxy String
i.body:
Stoxy String is a web component used for situtations, where you want to
display a single state object in the DOM, for example the current item count. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy String also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side. 

As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy String also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

j.title: Components: Stoxy String
j.headline: Attributes
j.body: Name Attribute   default Default value of the string, if no value is set

k.title: Components: Stoxy String
k.headline: Events
k.body: Name Attribute   updated Triggers when the state object observed by the stoxy element is updated. Event detail contains data about the new state.

l.title: Components: Stoxy String
l.headline: Usage
l.body:
import  '@stoxy/stoxy-string' ; 
  
< p >  < stoxy-string >  itemcount</ stoxy-string >  </ p >  
  
Say the state object of itemcount  was 5 at the moment, we would have our DOM as: 
< p >  < stoxy-string >  5</ stoxy-string >  </ p >  
  
        
          import '@rocket/launch/inline-notification/inline-notification.js';
         
      

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

m.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
m.headline: Components: Stoxy Repeat
m.body:
Stoxy Repeat is a web component used for iterating state content onto the web page. 
The repeat component is useful for situations where the state object is iterable
and is desired to be displayed as e.g. a list 

As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Repeat also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

n.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
n.headline: Attributes
n.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  id Identifier for the accessed iterable object

o.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
o.headline: Events
o.body: Name Attribute   updated Triggers when the state object observed by the stoxy element is updated. Event detail contains data about the new state.

p.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
p.headline: Usage

q.title: Methods: Add
q.headline: Methods: Add
q.body:
Add an element to the state object array by key. 
If not state atom for key is set, an empty array is initialized before adding object. 
Returns a promise.

r.title: Methods: Add
r.headline: Params
r.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  value Any possible storable value

s.title: Methods: Add
s.headline: Returns
s.body: A promise which resolves to the write result of the object: {key: string, value: any}

t.title: Methods: Add
t.headline: Usage

u.title: Methods: Add
u.headline: Specific add

v.title: Components: Stoxy Object
v.headline: Components: Stoxy Object
v.body:
Stoxy Object is a web component used for sections of content, where you want to
access multiple keys of a single state object. 
This can be useful for example when generating user profile pages. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Object also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side. 

As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Object also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

w.title: Components: Stoxy Object
w.headline: Attributes
w.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  prefix Prefix to access wanted state object properties. Makes it possible for Stoxy to recognize plain strings to replace.

x.title: Components: Stoxy Object
x.headline: Events
x.body: Name Attribute   updated Triggers when the state object observed by the stoxy element is updated. Event detail contains data about the new state.

1h.title: Methods: Sub
1h.headline: Methods: Sub
1h.body:
Subscribe to updates in state of wanted object. 
Allows you to programmatically react to state changes in wanted state objects

1i.title: Methods: Sub

1i.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  callback Callback Function to call when state of given key is updated

1l.title: Methods: Sub
1l.headline: Callback payload
1l.body:
The callback function is passed information about the event as a parameter, which can then be
used to easily react to the change.

1m.title: Methods: Sub
1m.headline: Callback params
1m.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Action type or the update event (Update on content update, Delete on successful clear of said key)  data Current data in said state

1z.title: Mixins: Element Mixin
1z.headline: Mixins: Element Mixin
1z.body:
The Element Mixin was created to allow developers to create Web Components with built in Stoxy state support. 
The Mixin allows the develper to declare state objects, default states and react to state updates without using
the functions of Stoxy Core. 
This mixin is aimed at people wanting to create interactive components which are aware of state changes around them
and react accordingly.

2a.title: Getting started: Core functionality
2a.headline: Getting started: Core functionality
2a.body:
Stoxy is a dynamic state management system, which allows the developer to handle state across the whole
application without hassle. 
Stoxy utilizes the IndexedDB  to persist
data across page reloads and navigation. The usage of IDB also means that state persisted onto it is accessible
even when the user is offline.

2b.title: Getting started: Core functionality
2b.headline: Persistance

2c.title: Getting started: Core functionality
2c.headline: Updates
2c.body:
Stoxy elements are a perfect tool for creating reactive web experiences. When using Stoxy elements, the developer
doesn't need to worry about reacting to state changes. The elements handle their state and updates to said state
automatically, without any input from the developer. 
The updates are ran in a dynamic fashion, and only the content that has updated will be changed. 
With elements like Stoxy Repeat , the iterable stateobject are
compared to their old state, and sorted automatically to match the new order of the
state array. Only the items in the wrong order are moved around the DOM, and the ones that didn't change order
will be kept untouched.

2d.title: Getting started: Core functionality
2d.headline: Reactivity
2d.body:
On top of the reactivity provided by the Stoxy elements, the developer can also subscribe to the
state updates happening around their web application. 
The developer is able to set a callback function to be called with the new data set onto the state, as the
state updates. This allows for reactive programming patterns to be done by the developer even without using
Stoxy elements. 
import  { sub}  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

sub ( "shoppingcart" ,  ( )  =>  console . log ( "Shopping card updated" ) ) ; 
  

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

2e.title: Getting started: Installation
2e.headline: Getting started: Installation
2e.body:
Stoxy can be installed as single packages or as a collection of all Stoxy elements and the core. 
To install the whole Stoxy project in one go, you can do so with 
npm  install  @stoxy/stoxy
  

Alternatively the packages can be installed as standalone installations

2f.title: Getting started: Installation
2f.headline: Stoxy core
2f.body:
THe functionality and core functions of Stoxy 
npm  install  @stoxy/core

2g.title: Getting started: Installation
2g.headline: Stoxy String
2g.body:
The stoxy string  element 
npm  install  @stoxy/string

2h.title: Getting started: Installation
2h.headline: Stoxy object
2h.body:
The stoxy object  element 
npm  install  @stoxy/object

2i.title: Getting started: Installation
2i.headline: Stoxy repeat
2i.body:
The stoxy repeat  element 
npm  install  @stoxy/repeat

2j.title: Getting started: Installation
2j.headline: Stoxy form
2j.body:
The stoxy form  element 
npm  install  @stoxy/form

2q.title: Recipes: Persisting data
2q.headline: Recipes: Persisting data
2q.body:
Persisting data means that the state persists through page reloads and even
navigation outside of the page. 
There are plenty of situtations where you might want to persist data. One example
would be persisting API data that doesn't update often, or implementing a Stale-While-Revalidate 
state management system 
Persisting data to IndexedDB isn't on by default, and needs to be opted in on a per-key basis. 
After declaring the key with persistKey  all the state of that key is persisted into the IndexedDB. 
import  {  persistKey }  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

persistKey ( "shoppingcart" ,  "userhistory" ) ;

2r.title: Recipes: Persisting data
2r.headline: Memory management
2r.body:
Persisting data onto the IndexedDB could also have a performance benefit. When persisting data, the Stoxy
system only keeps the latest 5 cache objects in memory cache, and let's the garbage collection handle older
state objects. 
This means that for an application using a large amount of state keys, it might be beneficial to persist the data
to enable the memory management benefits. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!
